channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-15202] Reduce garbage while setting response
item.description:
Probably this can move under HBASE-15177. During RpcServer#setResponse we do IPCUtil.getDelimitedMessageAsByteBuffer for the header and result. This internally creates a byte[], CodedOutputStream and a BB. Then the totalSize is also wrapped in a BB.
Finally all these BB are passed to BufferChain along with the Cellblock.
This JIRA is to reduce the number of objects that we create here and allow one BB from this header, result and total Size along with one CodedOutputStream and pass this BB along with the Cellblocks to the Bufferchain. From the JMC tool can observe around 2% lesser object allocation arising out of these objects.

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: Patch for QA.
Nice ramkrishna.s.vasudevan

Why are we doing toBytes on a CodedOutputStream to write an int when COS is filled with methods for int writing: https://developers.google.com/protocol-buffers/docs/reference/java/com/google/protobuf/CodedOutputStream Do you want to vint it anyway? Or is it that our protocol expects to see a non-vint'd int at this stage? If so, might want to doc what is going on with a comment.

Should we take care we don't overflow int calculating the message size?

Hopefully we can get rid of this allocation one day:

byte[] b = new byte[headerSerializedSize + headerVintSize + resultSerializedSize
449 + resultVintSize + Bytes.SIZEOF_INT];

Otherwise patch is great +1.

Or is it that our protocol expects to see a non-vint'd int at this stage?

Yes that is the reason. Infact wanted to go with existing int related APIs in COS. But here in RpcClientImpl 


int totalSize = in.readInt();

Here we want the way that DataInputStream can decode it. Hence we have to go with the byte[] way of writing int.

If so, might want to doc what is going on with a comment.

Okie. Will add comment.

Should we take care we don't overflow int calculating the message size?


  public static ByteBuffer getDelimitedMessageAsByteBuffer(final Message m) throws IOException {

    if (m == null) return null;

    int serializedSize = m.getSerializedSize();

    int vintSize = CodedOutputStream.computeRawVarint32Size(serializedSize);

Previously also we were doing the same. Am not sure whether the message sizes will overflow int because they are given by the Protobuf Message APIs. If it had the problem of overflowing then we should have had the same problem previously also?
Thanks for the immediate review Stack.
Updated patch with the required comment.

-1 overall

Ok. Thanks for adding comment. +1 after fixing checkstyle and javadoc complaint (if yours... even if not – smile)
And, yeah, we want the int to be raw serialization rather than pb vint.
Good one. Can we move Bytes.toBytes() to be inside IPCUtil instead. Bytes is a public facing class, and this CIS method is only for internal consumption. Other than that +1.

for (int i = 0; i <= 3; i++) {

969	      // Instead of iterating store in 4 vars and write as RawByte?

970	      cos.writeRawByte(b[i]);

971	    }

Can we do that comment what you wrote? So can avoid a byte[] creation. +1 for Enis suggestion to move it out of Bytes.java

Okie will update the checkstyle comments (it was an unused import) and will do the comment that I added. Infact I wanted to do hence added the comment but felt odd to do. But it is worthy doing it.
Thanks for all the reviews.

Updated patch. Moved the new API to IPCUtil. As said in the comment that was written in the patch, now we don't create byte[] also. So we have a reduction from 7 objects to 3 objects per setResponse. Also removed the unused import. Should be good for commit.

For writing the total size (int) we added new API to write to COS.
The COS is any way created wrapping a byte[] we made. Instead we can write the total size (int) directly to the byte[]?
Can use Bytes#putInt(byte[] bytes, int offset, int val)

Updated patch as per the comment from Anoop. Now directly writes the total Size to byte[] and rest is written by the COS. So we create a suitable COS on the byte[] from the required offset and length.
